title: Water Quality Along Three sites at the Poudre River
text:
about: This is data from my Watershed measurements class For this assignment we analyzed data from 2023 and looked at the patterns of water quality parameters. The graphs below display the monthly, hourly and yearly patternsat three sites along the Poudre river: Legacy Park, Lincoln Ave, Timberline rd.The parameters measured are depth, Conductivity, dissolved oxygen, average temperature,and pH.


source('setup.R')

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

Attaching package: 'rstatix'


The following object is masked from 'package:stats':

    filter



Attaching package: 'jsonlite'


The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':

    flatten



data <- read.csv("data/concise_df_wide.csv")
data$DT_round_mst <- ymd_hms(data$DT_round_mst)
hourly_data <- data %>%
 mutate(hour = floor_date(DT_round_mst, "hour")) %>%
 group_by(site, hour) %>%
 summarise(across(where(is.numeric), mean, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop") 

Warning: There was 1 warning in `summarise()`.
ℹ In argument: `across(where(is.numeric), mean, na.rm = TRUE)`.
ℹ In group 1: `site = "legacy"` and `hour = 2023-04-01 17:00:00`.
Caused by warning:
! The `...` argument of `across()` is deprecated as of dplyr 1.1.0.
Supply arguments directly to `.fns` through an anonymous function instead.

  # Previously
  across(a:b, mean, na.rm = TRUE)

  # Now
  across(a:b, \(x) mean(x, na.rm = TRUE))



daily_data <- data %>%
 mutate(date = as_date(DT_round_mst)) %>%
 group_by(site, date) %>%
 summarise(across(where(is.numeric), mean, na.rm = TRUE),.groups = "drop")


hourly_data_long <- hourly_data %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = c(Depth_ft, DO_mg.L, pH, Specific_Conductivity_uS.cm, Temperature_C),
    names_to = "Parameter",
    values_to = "Value"
  )


hourly_data_long <- hourly_data_long %>%
 mutate(date = as.Date(hour, format = "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S"))
sept_hour_data <- hourly_data_long %>%
 filter(date == as.Date("2023-09-19"))
ggplot(data = sept_hour_data) +
 geom_line(mapping = aes(x = hour, y = Value, color = Parameter)) +
 facet_grid(Parameter ~ site, scales = "free_y") +
 labs(
 x = "Hour",
 y = "WQ Parameter",
 title = "Trends Over Time by Hour (September 19th, 2023)"
 ) +
 theme_minimal() +
 theme(
 plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16),
 axis.title.x = element_text(size = 12),
 axis.title.y = element_text(size = 12),
 axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1), 
 legend.position = "right"
 )

Warning: Removed 22 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_line()`).










daily_long <- daily_data %>%
 pivot_longer(cols = c(Depth_ft, DO_mg.L, pH, Specific_Conductivity_uS.cm, Temperature_C),
 names_to = "Parameter",
values_to = "Value")


sept_daily <- daily_long %>%
 filter(format(date, "%Y-%m") == "2023-09")


ggplot(data = sept_daily) +
 geom_line(mapping = aes(x = date, y = Value, color = Parameter)) +
facet_grid( Parameter ~ site, scales = "free_y") +
 labs(
 x = "Date",
 y = "Value",
 title = "Trends Over Time by Date (september 2023)"
 ) +
 theme_minimal() +
 theme(
 plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
 axis.title.x = element_text(size = 12),
 axis.title.y = element_text(size = 12),
 axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),
 legend.position = "top")









ggplot(data = daily_long) +
 geom_line(mapping = aes(x = date, y = Value, color = Parameter)) +
facet_grid( Parameter ~ site, scales = "free_y") +
labs(x = "Date", y = "Value", title = "Trends Over Time by Date") +
theme_minimal() +
 theme(
plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16, face = "bold"),
axis.title.x = element_text(size = 12),
axis.title.y = element_text(size = 12),
axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1), legend.position = "top"
 )

title: Carolyn Rothmann
text: Hey yall! My name is Carolyn and I am a masters student a Colorado State University studying Water Resources. This website is my portfolio with some of projects from the Fall 2024 semester. Cheers!

title: The Relationship Between Surface Water and Groundwater
text:
How surface water interacts with groundwater at CSU Mountain Campus.


source("setup.R")

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors
Attaching package: 'rstatix'
The following object is masked from 'package:stats':
    filter
Attaching package: 'jsonlite'
The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':
    flatten



water_table <- read.csv("data/daily.csv")


Water Table Elevation

water_elevation <- water_table %>%
  mutate(date = ymd(date))


 water_elevation %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = date, y = h_m, color = site)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = .5) +  
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Water Table Elevation Over Time",
       x = "Date",
       y = "Elevation (m)")








This time series graph showing changes in water table elevation at the Colorado State University Mountain Campus from 2019 - 2024. The periodic spikes seen here shows the seasonal variation likely due to rain or snow melt.

rating_data <- read.csv("data/discharege_rating.csv")



Relationship between water stage and discharge.

rating_data %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Stage_CM, y = Q_CM, color = site)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(
    title = "Long Term Rating Curve for Sites 1 and 2",
    x = "Stage (cm)",
    y = "Discharge (cm)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()








This rating curve represents the relationship between the stage and discharge between upstream and downstream sites from 2019 - 2024. As the stage increases so does the rate of discharge in Little South Fork Stream.
